author: Jonathan Maus
title: Four rides to support Black lives
blurb: If you’ve been to one of the protests in Portland you’ve seen that the number of people on bikes is growing each night. Now community leaders have planned several bike rides that will amplify and/or spin-off the protests.

author: Kristian Foden-Vencil
title: People Are Struggling To Mourn Loved Ones Amid Pandemic Regulations
blurb: A few weeks into the coronavirus quarantine, Jan Stewart’s younger sister Tammy Stewart started suffering strange symptoms, like she couldn’t breathe. She ended up at Kaiser Sunnyside Hospital in Clackamas with COVID-19.

author: WW Staff
title: Portland-Based Mercy Corps Is Monitoring COVID-19 Infections in Developing Nations. But Good Data Is Hard to Come By.
blurb: Interim CEO Beth deHamel is concerned about the impact of the virus in places like Central America, Afghanistan and refugee camps.

author: Michael Russell
title: Another top Portland brunch restaurant calls it quits
blurb: Trinket, the cozy César E. Chávez Boulevard restaurant known for its veggie hash and duck eggs Benedict, will close permanently, owner Gina Helvie announced in an Instagram video Saturday.
address: 2035 SE Cesar Estrada Chavez Blvd, Portland, OR 97214

author: Latisha Jensen
title: A WW Delivery Driver Says Police Detained Him as He Restocked Newspaper Boxes in Downtown Portland
blurb: “Stop right there, get on your knees!” Greg Mitchell recalls the officer saying. “Put your hands up!”

author: Rachel Monahan and Aaron Mesh
title: Portland Reporter Pens First-Person Account of Being Pepper-Sprayed While Filming an Arrest
blurb: Donovan Farley, a longtime contributor to WW’s Arts & Culture section, says he was filming an arrest when he was pepper-sprayed in the eyes.

author: Nigel Jaquiss
title: City of Portland Drops Opposition to More Frequent Free Meal Distribution in City Parks
blurb: The group Free Hot Soup claims victory in its legal battle to serve the hungry.

author: Meerah Powell
title: Beauty And Aesthetics Workers Navigate Returning To Work Amid Coronavirus
blurb: Ceanna Lee is going back to work at her salon, MODA Studios, in Beaverton.

author: By Rachel Monahan, Tess Riski, and Latisha Jensen
title: Protests and Riots Fill the Streets of Portland. Four Black Leaders Are Trying to Bring Meaning to the Anguish.
blurb: What makes this moment so perilous and important is, we simply don’t know how long it will last or what it will mean. So we asked four black leaders at the center of the struggle.
address: 700 N Rosa Parks Way, Portland, OR 97217

author: Shannon Gormley
title: Portland’s Japanese Garden Will Reopen This Week
blurb: One of Portland's biggest tourist attractions, the Japanese Garden had to lay off 90 percent of its employees when it shut down in March.
